awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Medium: Collaborative: New Directions in Public-Key and Identity-Based Encryption
awd_abstract_narration:
Developments in public-key encryption (PKE) and identity-based encryption (IBE) have revolutionized the field of cryptography and secure communication in general. PKE allowed remote parties to establish secure channels in front of eavesdropping adversaries, and led to public-key directories storing parties' public-keys. The stronger primitive of IBE eliminated the need for a large public-key directory, though this comes at the cost of trusting a central private-key generation authority. Decades after introduction of PKE and IBE, our understanding of the complexity of these tasks, in terms of what they can offer and the intractability assumptions needed for building them, is still very limited. At a high level, the goal of the project is to make progress exactly on these fronts. The project's novelties include a study of new cryptographic tools that give best of both IBE and PKE as well as developing new techniques for basing IBE and PKE on optimal intractability assumptions. The project impact is through new ways to secure communication. In addition, the collaboration between the investigators will help enhance the education of the graduate students at both institutes.

More specifically, the goals of this project are pursued in two directions: (1) enhancements from minimal assumptions and (2) identifying barriers and proving lower bounds. The first direction of the project focuses on obtaining enhanced security for IBE and PKE from minimal assumptions. The efforts above on designing constructions from minimal assumptions would not be complete without having a formal understanding about when we have achieved optimal results. The second principal component of this project focuses on identifying those minimal assumptions. Specifically, the project's goal is to prove black-box and non-black-box barriers and (efficiency) lower bounds, complementing the results proved in the first direction.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Developments in public-key encryption (PKE) and identity-based encryption (IBE) have revolutionized the field of cryptography. Public-key cryptography allowed remote parties to establish secure channels in front of eavesdropping adversaries, and led to public-key directories storing parties' public-keys. The stronger primitive of identity-based encryption,  eliminated the need for a large public-key directory, though this comes at the cost of trusting a central private-key generation authority. Decades after introduction of PKE and IBE,  our understanding of the complexity of these tasks, both in terms of what they can offer and the intractability assumptions needed for building them, is still very limited.

This project developed new constructions of PKE and IBE offering new advantages over the state-of-the-art. For example, this work realizes variants of identity-based encryption methods --- called registration-based encryption --- that do not suffer from the key-escrow problem. This new primitive is the focus of significant effort by the community to construct various flavors of regstration based encryption --- including efforts to obtain practical constructions.

This project investigated a set of fundamental primitives in cryptography that  have (or are expected to have) a profound effect on our lives through shaping new ways for secure communication. In addition to the direct societal benefits that this research will bring,  the collaboration between the PIs helped enhance the education of the graduate students at both institutes.
